awd_abstract_narration:
Symmetric function theory is an area of mathematical research which has produced an abundance of intricate (and sometimes conjectural) identities, many of which are very difficult to prove. Symmetric functions have ties to geometry, representation theory, and physics, and there is a deep interplay between these areas: symmetric functions give a computational model for difficult matters in these other fields, and symmetric function identities are often best understood as shadows of deeper concepts from other areas. This project studies the algebraic and geometric underpinnings of a symmetric function problem called the Delta Conjecture. The project provides research training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students.

Quotients of the polynomial ring in n variables have classical ties to the combinatorics of permutations and the geometry of the flag variety. This project studies analogous quotients (and subspaces) of a newer ring called 'superspace' which has n commuting generators (corresponding to bosons) and n anticommuting generators (corresponding to fermions). These new algebraic objects are linked to the combinatorics of ordered set partitions (as studied by Haglund, Shimozono, and the PI) and the geometry of a variety of spanning line configurations introduced by Pawlowski and the PI. A deep conjecture of Zabrocki, and a related conjecture of Wilson and the PI, assert that (a variant of) superspace gives a representation-theoretic model for the Delta Conjecture. The PI will use the algebra and geometry of superspace to tie other areas of mathematics to the Delta Conjecture, which could lead to an illuminating proof thereof.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The PI performed research in focused on symmetries of various objects motivated by combinatorics, physics, and geometry, and understanding quantities left invariant under these symmetries. A major actor in the PI's research was the "superspace ring" of mathematical physics. Superspace has commuting and anti-commuting generators which physicists use to describe the states of bosons (where multiple, identical particles can occupy the same state at the same time) and fermions (where the Pauli Exclusion Princple forbids two particles from occupying the same state at once). The case of all commuting generators has been studied for a long time in algebra and combinatorics; the addition of anticommuting generators is a relative newcomer to our field and has exhibited many interesting properties.

Along with his collaborators, the PI studied a natural action of the full permutation group on n objects on the superspace ring of rank n. The PI defined extensions of the flag variety and the Vandermonde determinant to the superspace ring and solved conjectures on the structure of the ring obtained from superspace by quotienting out by permutation invariants. These structures (and closely related objects) exhibited surprising connections to the Kauffman skein relation of knot theory, mysterious positivity properties of a new geometrically inspired symmetric function operation of "Chern plethysm", and the study of Macdonald polynomials in the ring of symmetric functions.

The research of the PI is in algebraic combinatorics, a field whose problems tend to have a low barrier to entry while ultimately exhibiting connections to deep mathematical ideas. As such, the research program of the PI is well-suited to recruiting early-career people to science and mathematics. During the lifetime of this grant, the PI mentored three postdoctoral scholars, advised seven Ph.D. students and multiple undergraduates, and served as a mentor in research conferences at the University of Minnesota and Hokkaido University focused on early-career mathematicians.
